article.title: Bars & boxy/peanut bulges in thin & thick discs: I. Morphology and line-of-sight velocities of a fiducial model

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the dashed and solid lines in Figure 1 represent?
choices: Solid: Radial velocity dispersion, Dashed: Tangential velocity dispersion
Solid: Vertical velocity dispersion, Dashed: Radial velocity dispersion
Solid: Radial velocity dispersion, Dashed: Vertical velocity dispersion
Solid: Total velocity dispersion, Dashed: Radial velocity dispersion

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the most striking morphological difference between the thin and thick disc bars in Figure 2?
choices: The thin disc bar is significantly longer than the thick disc bar.
The thick disc bar is boxier and rounder than the elongated thin disc bar.
The thin disc bar shows a pronounced X-shape while the thick disc bar does not.
The thick disc bar shows clear spiral arm features extending from its ends, while the thin disc bar does not.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the different lines in Figure 3 represent, and what trend do they illustrate?
choices: Blue: Thin disc, Red: Thick disc, Black: Total. The thin disc components are always stronger than their thick disc counterparts.
Blue: Total, Red: Thin disc, Black: Thick disc. The total bar strength is always dominated by the thin disc.
Blue: Thick disc, Red: Thin disc, Black: Total. Thick disc components become increasingly dominant at larger radii.
Blue: Total, Red: Thick disc, Black: Thin disc. The total b/p strength is always weaker than both the thin and thick disc b/ps.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend does the color gradient in Figure 5 illustrate?
choices: The thin disc fraction increases with increasing height above the plane.
The thick disc fraction is dominant in the central regions of the galaxy.
The thin disc fraction is highest at intermediate heights above the plane.
The thin disc fraction decreases with increasing distance from the plane.
